Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Singapore
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Loretta Au of Stony Brook University to conduct a research project, entitled "Quantifying the influence of mutations on protein structure and function," during the summer of 2012 at the National University of Singapore in Singapore, Singapore. The host scientist is Dr. Christopher Hogue.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is its integration of mathematics and biochemistry to understand how the function of a protein changes when amino-acid substitutions are made to the original sequence. Detecting and measuring these effects can help highlight regions in a protein that are involved in a specific function, as well as the extent to which that function may be changed. Knowing this can help guide projects in protein engineering, by suggesting where modifications should be made to yield a stable protein with a novel or improved function and also by providing a sense of which proteins might serve as ideal models for design.

The Broader Impact of this work is to help develop software for learning about protein evolution in a classroom or laboratory setting. Experimental methods are often limited to studying proteins that have been able to adapt or overcome natural selection; our computational approach can simulate a variety of mutations, including those that deteriorate protein integrity. These examples provide biophysical and biochemical reasons for how modifications are able to improve or worsen protein stability and function. The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Closely related proteins have similar amino acid sequences, but may have large variations in structure and function from each other. The differences in their sequences make diversity in biological responses possible, despite having limitations on the number of expressed proteins in living organisms. Understanding how individual positions influence aspects of protein fitness, such as structural stability and binding affinity, requires disentangling the multiple roles that a single position may have. Preliminary results have identified the roles of individual positions, and the research funded by this fellowship was used to understand how interactions between them contribute to fitness.

The intellectual merit of this project is its integration of biochemistry and mathematics to understand the relationships between different positions that share a common role in fitness. Changes were made systematically to the original sequence, and the effects of these mutations were measured for individual positions, as well as relevant pairs. Comparing the energetic difference between paired and corresponding positions allowed us to identify any dependencies between them, and locate the most significant interactions in maintaining structural integrity or binding affinity. We developed a protocol that quantifies the extent that advantageous changes can be made to a protein, and these interactions can also be mapped out for any protein domain of interest. An understanding of where modifications can significantly impact protein folding or other properties will be beneficial in protein engineering projects, where the goal may be to further stabilize or introduce novel functions to a protein.

The broader impact of this research is its potential in designing educational software for the classroom or other research laboratories. Experimental methods are limited to proteins that have survived selective pressures, so sequences with unfavorable mutations can never be used in analysis—our computational method can model these missing sequences, providing some perspective on the reasons that evolution selected against certain kinds of mutation. The broader impact of the EAPSI fellowship is in the experience of conducting research in Singapore, which made it possible to experience the scientific infrastructure and research policies of Singapore first-hand. The fellowship also provided opportunities for international collaborations, which have continued since the completion of this project.
